title: Атлас рутульских диалектов
text:
На сайте представлены результаты диалектологического обследования двенадцати рутульских сёл, расположенных в Рутульском и Ахтынском районах Республики Дагестан (Россия). Это сёла Амсар, Джилихур, Ихрек, Кала, Кина, Киче, Куфа, Лучек, Мюхрек, Рутул, Хнов, Шиназ.
Рутульский язык принадлежит к лезгинской ветви нахско-дагестанской языковой семьи. Большинство носителей этого языка (около 33 тысяч человек, согласно переписи 2020 года) проживают в Дагестане.
Рутульские диалекты были обследованы в июле 2022 года в рамках лингвистической экспедиции Школы лингвистики НИУ ВШЭ (Москва). Опрос носителей рутульских диалектов проводился по единой анкете, составленной участниками исследовательской группы. При составлении анкеты были учтены имеющиеся описания рутульских диалектов (Ибрагимов 2004, 1978; Alekseyev 2016, 1994; Алисултанов, Сулейманова 2019; Исмаилова 2011; Исламов 2014; Алисултанов, Исламов 2022; Махмудова 2002; Ибрагимова 2009; Authier б. д.-b, б. д.-a, 2023; Дирр 1912; Джамалов 2006). При этом мы стремились не только задокументировать и количественно оценить уже известные параметры диалектного варьирования, но и по возможности выявить новые, ранее не изученные региональные варианты.
Для каждого исследуемого явления было составлено несколько предложений-стимулов на русском языке. В каждой обследованной деревне были записаны переводы этих предложений двумя, тремя или четырьмя носителями. Исследовались диалектные различия в области лексики, фонетики, морфологии и синтаксиса.
Нашей основной целью являлось систематическое картирование диалектной вариативности. Вариативность в реализации того или иного явления (отражается на картах разным цветом) отмечается не только между деревнями, но и между жителями одной деревни, а иногда и в речи одного говорящего. Такие случаи отражены на карте в виде кружков, содержащих доли разного цвета. Относительная частотность вариантов на картах не отражается.
Диалектные различия, представленные в Атласе, основаны исключительно на нашем исследовании. Поэтому возможна ситуация, когда некоторая диалектная черта не отражена на карте Атласа для определенной деревни, притом что она отмечена в литературе. Иными словами, Атлас отражает диалектное разнообразие рутульского языка лишь частично.







Авторы проекта выражают глубокую благодарность жителям рутульских сёл за их гостеприимство и готовность переводить, объяснять и помогать.



Anastasia Alekseeva, Nikita Beklemishev, Michael Daniel, Nina Dobrushina, Konstantin Filatov, Anastasia Ivanova, Timur Maisak, Maxim Melenchenko, George Moroz, Ivan Netkachev, Ilya Sadakov. Atlas of Rutul dialects. Moscow: Linguistic Convergence Laboratory, HSE University. https://lingconlab.github.io/rutul_dialectology/index.html



Проект поддерживается Международной лабораторией языковой конвергенции. Корпус создан в рамках Программы фундаментальных исследований НИУ ВШЭ.

title: Scalar additive context
text: Scalar additive semantics (“even X did Y”, where X is the least likely element to do Y) is usually expressed by an additive particle. However, in some cases, the additive is required to combine with another element, -kina/-kine, in other to convey scalar additive meaning (and not just additive one).

title: Presence of additive in non-specific indefinite pronouns
text: In some dialects, additive particles optionally occur in non-specific indefinite pronouns. There is, furthermore, some variation as to whether the additive occurs between the WH-word and the suffix signaling indefiniteness (thus “inside” the pronoun) or if it occurs after the indefinite suffix (thus “outside” the pronoun).

title: Presence of additive in non-specific indefinite pronouns
Non-specific indefinite pronouns
text: Non-specific indefinite pronouns are derived from WH-pronouns (known to speaker, unknown to hearer). There is variation across the dialect as to (1) which suffixes are attached to WH-pronouns and (2) whether those suffixes attach to WH-pronouns directly or a copula occurs between them. In many cases, the suffix deriving non-specific pronouns is identical with the suffix for counterfactual conditionals (e.g., de/jde). Furthermore, non-specifics may optionally attach an additive particle, but, on this map, the presence of additives is not shown.

title: Hypothetical conditional converb suffix
text: The suffix for the hypothetical conditional converb (“If X, then Y”).

title: Exponence of «sequential» temporal semantics
text: The basic temporal semantics of sequence of events (“when X occured, Y occured”) is expressed either with a dedicated converb affix or a separate construction. Some constructions involve the participles combined with a locative case marker.

title: Conjunction particle
text: The form of the conjunction for noun phrases (“A and B”).

title: Concessive marking
text: In most cases, concessive semantics (“Although X, Y”) is expressed by a combination of a conditional converb and an additive particle. However, some dialects allow for other constuctions as well — to convey concessive meaning, additive may attach to non-conditional verbforms. Parataxis (i.e. juxtaposition of two finite clauses) is also a frequent strategy to express this semantics.

title: Additive particle
text: The form of the additive particle (identical to the meaning of English “too”).

title: Stems of reflexive pronouns
text: This feature shows the specific forms of reflexive stems used in reflexive pronouns such as ‘themselves’. There were eight distinct stimuli to distinguish between singular / plural referents of all four genders. The speakers were asked to translate eight sentences: ‘The boy came himself’ (gender I), ‘The girl came herself’ (gender II), ‘The cow came itself’ (gender III), ‘The wall broke down by itself’ (gender IV), and their plural counterparts. For each speaker, first reaction was coded (although the elicitor tried to make sure that this reaction was not an error due to the misunderstanding of the context). With singular gender I referent (‘boy’), the majority of the villages used slightly different phonetic versions of the default root wɨǯ / vɨǯ / wuǯ / viǯ / wiǯ. The precise phonetic and phonemic analysis of this root across dialects has not been done yet. It seems that in the Khnov dialect, the vowel in this root resembles /i/ more than /ɨ/. In Kina, a special form juǯ was used. With singular gender II referent (‘girl’), speakers in Khnov and one speaker in Kiche used the same root, while in other villages a special gender II form was used: riǯ. With singular gender III referent (‘cow’), all the speakers used the “default” root (with dialectal phonetic varations). With singular gender IV referent (‘wall’), speakers in Khnov and Kiche used the same root, while in other villages a special gender IV form was used: jiǯ. With plural referents, almost all the time speakers used the root ǯor / ǯʷer / ǯʷär in all genders. Variance is attested with gender IV (‘wall’), in which some speakers in the northwestern villages used the singular form jiǯ.

title: Plural of ‘who’
text: This feature shows the form of the pronoun ‘who?’ in absolutive plural and ergative plural. The speakers were asked to translate sentences ‘[Some people just came.] Who came?’ (absolutive) and ‘[Some people did this.] Who did this?’ (ergative). For each speaker, first reaction was coded (although the elicitor tried to make sure that this reaction was not an error due to the misunderstanding of the context). In the absolutive, speakers in Khnov and Rutul and some speakers in adjacent villages used the usual singular root ‘who?’ without modification. In other villages, speakers used the singular root with the plural marker -er attached to it. In the ergative, most villages use the singular root without modification. At the same time, several speakers from Kufa and Kala used a special ergative plural stem: hal-aš(e). Several speakers (from Khnov and some other villages) used the absolutive root in the ergative context, which was coded as OTHER.

title: First person reflexive construction
text: This feature shows the choice of pronoun which is used in reflexive contexts in the 1st person: the 1st person pronoun or the reflexive pronoun. The speakers were asked to translate the following sentence: ‘I’ll go pour myself some tea’ (in Russian: ‘Пойду-ка я налью себе чаю’). For each speaker, first reaction was coded (although the elicitor tried to make sure that this reaction was not an error due to the misunderstanding of the context). In all villages except Khnov, the 1st person pronoun (zɨ[je] / zad in absolutive, zas in dative) was used, while Khnov speakers used the reflexive pronoun.

title: Ergative stem of negative pronouns
text: This feature shows the distribution of the stem suffixes used in the ergative forms of the negative pronoun ‘no one‘. This suffix is attached to the ergative root hal ‘who?’ to derive the ergative stem, followed by the ergative case suffix. The speakers were asked to translate the sentence ‘Nobody did this’. For each speaker, first reaction was coded (although the elicitor tried to make sure that this reaction was not an error due to the misunderstanding of the context). The suffix -n(n)i- was attested in Kina and adjacent villages, -na- in Rutul and Kufa, and -ne- in other villages.

title: Ergative marker of negative pronouns
text: This feature shows the distribution of the ergative case suffixes used in the ergative forms of the negative pronoun ‘no one‘. This suffix is attached to the ergative stem of the pronoun. The speakers were asked to translate the sentence ‘Nobody did this’. For each speaker, first reaction was coded (although the elicitor tried to make sure that this reaction was not an error due to the misunderstanding of the context). Reactions which did not feature the ergative root hal ‘who?’ and expressed the given meaning in other ways were coded as OTHER. The feature shows great variance in form of the case suffix. The null suffix is used in Rutul and Kufa; -ra in Kina and Dzhilikhur; -r is used in other cases.

title: Contrastive anaphoric demonstrative
text: This feature shows the distribution of demonstratives used in a contrastive anaphoric context. In this feature, not the village-specific form but the choice of one of the three demonstratives is coded. Speakers were asked to translate the stimulus: ‘Rasul came to Magomed’s house, and that one didn’t let him in’ (in Russian: ‘…а тот его не пустил’). For each speaker, first reaction was coded (although the elicitor tried to make sure that this reaction was not an error due to the misunderstanding of the context). Presence or absence of the emphatic prefix ha-/he- and the specific form of the attributive suffix were ignored for this feature. In most cases, the medial demonstrative (ha-/hawa-) was used but sometimes speakers’ first reaction used the distal demonstrative.

title: Absolutive marker of negative pronouns
text: This feature shows the distribution of the suffixes used in the absolutive forms of the negative pronoun ‘no one‘. This suffix is used to derive the negative pronoun from the absolutive root ‘who?’. The speakers were asked to translate the sentence ‘Nobody came’. For each speaker, first reaction was coded (although the elicitor tried to make sure that this reaction was not an error due to the misunderstanding of the context). The feature shows great variance in form of the absolutive suffix. While the variant -ne / -nä is used by many speakers in different villages, many others are attested as well: -nen in Ikhrek, -nɨ in Myukhrek, -na in Kina, -nik in Shinaz, -ni and -neki / -näki in different villages.

title: Wish formula ‘Good morning’
text: One and the same formula borrowed from Azerbaijani is used as a morning greeting in all villages. The formula is constructed from words of Arabic origin: sabaħ ‘morning’ and χajir ‘good, benefit’.

title: Universal concessive conditional converb suffixes
text: Universal concessive conditional converbs are used in subordinate clauses in such sentences as ‘Wherever you go, I’ll go with you’. This converb can be marked by a suffix or by a combination of a suffix and an additive particle. Note that only the use of the additive particle on the converb itself was mapped. In some cases, the additive particle can be placed in a different position in the clause; in this case, its presence is not reflected on the map.

title: Stem consonant deletion in Perfective forms of the verb ‘do’
text: The perfective stem of the verb ‘do’ can contain an ejective uvular root consonant - haq’ɨr. In most dialects, however, this consonant has changed into a glottal stop.

title: Stem consonant deletion in Perfective forms of the verb ‘do’
Optative
text: Optative suffixes vary across dialects. Suffixes -j, -xʲ, -x, -š, -k, -kij and -jkij are attested in our data.

title: Hortative marking
text: Hortative (or 1st person plural imperative) conveys an invitation to a joint action. Hortatives can be expressed by a combination of the imperative of the verb ‘go’ or a special particle (HORT.PTCL) with the infinitive of the main verb. In some dialects, when used alone, the imperative of the verb ‘go’ or the hortative particle can be used with a hortative meaning ‘let’s go!’ (cf. the map Hortative ‘Let’s go!’).

title: Differentiation of the optative and the jussive
text: The jussive (or 3rd person imperative) can be expressed by the same form as the optative (expression of blessings and curses). In other words, this feature answers the question whether the same form is used in the sentences ‘Let your parents come to school’ and ‘May Allah help you’.

title: Differentiation of the optative and the jussive
Causative from transitive verbs
text: Transitive verbs can form causatives in several different ways. The most frequent one is to combine the infinitive of the main verb with the complex verb maǯbɨr hɨʔɨr (‘force do’, dialect of Rutul). The combination of the infinitive with the verb wɨr (‘give’, dialect of Rutul) is also common. Interestingly, in the dialect of Rutul contaminated constructions with the verb maǯbɨr hɨʔɨr and the verb wɨr were used several times. Much more rarely, the verbs guǯ hɨʔɨr ‘force do’, sigɨr ‘let’, bɨjɨrmiš / bijirmiš hɨʔɨr (‘order do’) or huxur (‘say’, dialect of Amsar) have been recorded as translations of our stimuli.

title: Verb form used in present habitual contexts
text: The map shows the choice of verb forms in present habitual contexts (‘He always cooks meat without salt’, ‘She milks the cow every evening’). Most varieties use the present habitual form, which is a periphrastic form consisting of the imperfective converb and the present-tense copula (IPFV.CVB + COP). In some varieties, the copula is omitted and the form is thus syncretic with the bare converb (IPFV.CVB). In some varieties, the converb marker -r / -rV is dropped and the lexical part is represented by the imperfective stem (IPFV + COP). Some varieties use the present tense in this context, which is a periphrastic form with another auxiliary verb (IPFV.CVB + ‘be’). See also @FeatureX and @FeatureXX on the imperfective forms.

title: Verb form used in present habitual contexts
The verb ‘say’: perfective and imperfective stems
text: The main speech verb ‘say’ is a high-frequency verb in Rutul, with cross-dialectal variation in the forms of aspectual stems. For the perfective stem, the stimulus sentence was ‘He told the truth’. In the Rutul translation, one of the forms based on the perfective stem (usually, the aorist) was used. For the imperfective stem, the stimulus sentence was ‘He always says “yes”’. In the Rutul translation, one of the periphrastic present tense forms based on the imperfective converb or participle was used. As the map value, only the stems are given, without converb or participle suffixes. The gender is unmarked in this stem (in the “weak” gender agreement series, Gender 4 has a zero affix).

title: The verb ‘say’: perfective and imperfective stems
The verb ‘say’: perfective and imperfective stems
The verb ‘become’: infinitive
text: The verb ‘become’ is one of the most frequent verbs in Rutul. It has several suppletive stems, with cross-dialectal variation in their phonological form. For the infinitive stem, the stimulus sentence was ‘The apples will become red in autumn’. In the Rutul translation, the periphrastic future or prospective forms based on the infinitive were used. As the map value, the infinitive form is given. The gender is unmarked in this stem (in the “weak” gender agreement series, neuter plural has zero affix).

title: The verb ‘become’: imperative and prohibitive
text: The verb ‘become’ is one of the most frequent verbs in Rutul. It has several suppletive stems, with cross-dialectal variation in their phonological form. For the imperative, the stimulus sentence was ‘Become a doctor!’ (addressed to a boy). For the prohibitive (negative imperative), the stimulus sentence was ‘Don’t become a doctor!’ (addressed to a boy). The prohibitive prefix is ma- / me-. As the map value, the full form of the imperative or prohibitive is given. The gender is unmarked in both forms (in the “weak” gender agreement series, masculine has zero affix).

title: Stative verb ‘remain’: past
text: In the past tense, the synthetic form of the stative verb ‘remain’ is used in the majority of varieties, followed by the past tense suffix -j (e.g. mara-j ‘remained’). In Khnov, the past form is periphrastic, and both the stative and the copula carry the Khnov past suffix -na, e.g. maa-na i-na (remain<1>-CVB COP-PST) ‘remained’.

title: Stative verb ‘remain’: negative past
text: In the negative past, the stative verbs take the past tense suffix -ij in the majority of varieties (e.g. mardiš-ij ‘did not remain’). In Khnov, the past tense suffix is -na (e.g. mardiš-na).

title: Stative verb ‘remain’ with a prefix ǯV
text: In some Rutul varieties, stative verb ‘remain’ may have a prefix ǯa-/ǯe-. The existence of the prefix has not been reported in the literature. The stimuli were ‘My father/My mother is still at home’, ‘My car is still in the yard’ and ‘There is still water in the bucket’. The prefix is never obligatory to use; its contribution to the meaning of the verb is unclear. For instance, in Kina variety the sentence ‘My mother is still at home’ can be translated both as izdɨ nin χala mara (my mother at.home remains) and izdɨ nin heleki χala ǯe-mara (my mother at.home ǯe-remains). The map shows whether it is possible to add ǯa-/ǯe- to the stative verb ‘remain’.

title: Stative verb ‘remain’ with a prefix ǯV
Stative verb ‘be’: periphrastic present
text: Stative verbs can have a short form and a long form of the present tense. The long form is periphrastic and consists of the converbial form of the stative and the present-tense copula. Both the long form and the short form of the copula can occur in such periphrastic constructions (e.g. a-ni jiʔi vs. a-ni i ‘IN.be 1.COP’ in Kina). In some varieties, the long form is contracted, with the copula becoming suffixed to the stative verb (e.g. a-na-w ‘IN.be-3’ < **a-na w-i* ‘IN.be-CVB 3-COP’ in Shinaz). The maps below show the distribution of the long present tense forms.

title: Stative verb ‘be’: negative present
text: In the negative present, stative verbs employ the suffix which is identical to the negative present-tense copula. It is -diš in the majority of varieties (e.g. a-diš ‘is not there’), and -ǯiš in Shinaz.

title: Prospective participle
text: The prospective participle is derived from the infinitive by means of the attributive marker -dɨ. We observed no variation in this feature across Rutul varieties.

title: Present
text: Most indicative verb forms in Rutul are periphrastic and include a lexical verb and a postposed auxiliary. In most varieties, the present tense consists of the imperfective converb and a stative verb a ‘be’ (huʁar-a ‘it is raining’). In Khnov, the form consists of the imperfective converb and the positive copula i.

title: Perfective participle
text: The perfective participle is derived from the perfective stem by means of the attributive marker -d. We observed no variation in this feature across Rutul varieties.

title: Negative present habitual
text: Most indicative verb forms in Rutul are periphrastic and include a lexical verb and a postposed auxiliary. The form of the negative present habitual consists of the imperfective converb and the negative copula diš (e.g. deʔer-diš ‘does not smoke’). In Shinaz, a phonological shift to ǯiš took place.

title: Negative perfect
text: Most indicative verb forms in Rutul are periphrastic and include a lexical verb and a postposed auxiliary. Negative perfect consists of the general perfective converb and the negative form adiš of the stative verb a ‘be’. In Shinaz, a phonological shift to aǯiš took place. In Khnov, the positive and negative perfect forms are absent.

title: Negative copula: present tense
text: In the present tense, the negative copula has an invariable suppletive form, which does not inflect for gender. It is diš in the majority of varieties; and only in Shinaz a phonological shift to ǯiš took place.

title: Negative aorist
text: Most indicative verb forms in Rutul are periphrastic and include a lexical verb and a postposed auxiliary. Negative aorist (perfective past) consists of the general perfective converb and the negative copula. The negative copula is suppletive to the positive copula and does not inflect for gender. It is diš in the majority of varieties; only in Shinaz a phonological shift to ǯiš took place.

title: Meditative content question
text: Meditative questions are questions that do not require an answer from the addressee; often, such questions are self-addressed. In Rutul, special verb forms or special clitic markers are often used in meditative questions. In meditative content questions, a special marker is a dedicated suffix on the verb form, usually on the auxiliary verb i or a. The auxiliary marked with a dedicated suffix can follow the question word, in this case the verb takes a participial form. The specialized suffix has an initial consonant /d/ or /t/.

title: Indirect content question marker
text: In independent content questions, the verb is unmarked and ordinary indicative verb forms are employed. However, in indirect (embedded) content questions, verbs in the subordinate clause often take special forms, different from finite verb forms used in independent content questions. There is high variation in Rutul varieties with respect to the form of a suffix, which is employed in the verb forms in indirect content questions. In the stimuli sentences, the verbs in embedded clauses express (perfective) past, present and future meaning, hence usually periphrastic forms based on the perfective converb, imperfective converb and infinitive are used. The value shows the form of the suffix which follows a finite form (including auxiliary verb i or a). The value “no marking” means that an ordinary finite indicative form is used in the embedded clause.

title: Indicative verb form based on the perfective participle
text: In the verb paradigm of most Rutul varieties, there is a form based on the perfective participle. In the affirmative, it employs the copula as an auxiliary verb; in the negative, it employs the negative copula. The form expresses experiential past, e.g. izdɨ dide χalbɨr hɨʔɨt’i ‘My father built houses’ (Luchek) refers to a known fact about the past rather than a particular event in the past in a sequence of events. The map shows whether the form based on the perfective participle was accepted by the speakers. Note that in affirmative forms, the attributive marker -d before the copula can optionally shift to -t’ in some varieties (Kina, Luchek, Kala, Kiche).

title: Indicative verb form based on the perfective participle
Indicative verb form based on the perfective participle
Imperfective participle
text: The imperfective participle is derived from the imperfective stem by means of the attributive marker -d. We observed no variation in this feature across Rutul varieties.

title: Copula: present tense
text: In the present tense, the affirmative copula can have either a long or a short form. The long form is jiʔi, with a prefixal gender marker (jiʔi in Genders 1/4, r-iʔi in Gender 2, w-iʔi in Gender 3 in the singular). The short copula is i, with or without a prefixal gender marker depending on the variety. In some varieties, only the long or only the short copula occurs in the translations of the stimuli.

title: Continuative construction
text: The combination of the imperfective converb of the lexical verb and the auxiliary verb ma‹b›a ‘remain, still be’ expresses the continuative meaning ‘is still doing’. The first map shows the presence of the construction in Rutul varieties. If another means of expression was used to convey the continuative meaning (e.g., a simple present tense, or an adverb ‘still’), the value is coded as “OTHER”. An adverbial form of adjectives in combination with the verb ma‹b›a (e.g. načaʁ-na mara ‘is still ill’) is coded as an instance of the continuative construction. The second map shows the value of gender agreement on the verb in a continuative construction with a transitive verb (‘The mother is still milking the cow’). Although, according to the general rule, the agreement controller should be the absolutive noun phrase (here, ‘cow’, Gender 3), in the continuative construction agreemens tends to be with the ergative subject (here, ‘mother’, Gender 2).

title: Continuative construction
section: Gender agreement in the auxiliary verb
text:
Gender agreement in the auxiliary verb

КартаДанные

title: Aorist: presence of the copula
text: Depending on the variety, the short copula i may be present or absent in the affirmative Aorist. In Amsar, the copula is consistently absent, as confirmed by both informants. Across other settlements, no consistency is observable. For Khnov, the value of this feature is marked as “OTHER”, because the long copula -iʔi is used, with the converb marker -r being omitted.

title: Anterior converb
text: Ibragimov (1978: 220; 2004: 187) descibes a “pre-future” tense in Ikhrek dialect, which is absent ni Mukhad dialect, cf.: “Преждебудущее (в мух. диалекте отсутствует) образуется от основы причастия наст. вр. плюс формант инфинитива -ис (ср.: I сат-ад-ис, II сарт-ад-ис… ‘оставлен будет’)”. According to our data, the form in -dis is a temporal converb, only used in dependent clauses, with the meaning ‘before P’, cf. gʷalaχ waʔadis… ‘Before s/he started to work…’ (Kina). The map shows the presence of this form in Rutul varities.

title: Lexical item for ‘whip’
text: The map shows lexical items for the concept ‘whip’.

text: The map shows lexical items for the concept ‘hot’.

text: The map shows lexical items for the concept ‘horse’.

text: The map shows lexical items for the concept ‘cow’.

title: Lexical item for ‘bone’
text: The map shows lexical items for the concept ‘bone’.

title: Superlative
text: The map shows the expression of the superlative degree of comparison (‘X is the Y-est (of Z)’). The stimulus ‘She is the most beautiful girl in the village’ was used, and only the first answer was taken into account. In all cases, the expression was periphrastic. The map shows the choice of the function word in the construction. Ibragimov (2004: 75) mentions modifiers bala ‘much’ and lap ‘very’ as ones which are used with adjectives to express the superlative degree. However, these words are originally intensifiers rather than superlative markers (cf. ‘very beautiful’ and ‘the most beautiful’). Our stimulus includes the designation of the set of entities involved in the comparison (‘in the village’), and this allows to eliminate the intensifier interpretation (cf. ‘#She is a very beautiful girl in the village’) and to show the truly superlative functioning of the modifiers. Other options, more apparently dedicated, include the Russian modifier samɨj ‘most’, the modifier derived from the demonstrative haːsa ‘such’, the ordinal numeral saxusdɨ ‘first’ and the word sin ‘all’ used as the standard of comparison (i.e. ‘of all’).

title: Oblique stem of the numeral ‘two’
text: The maps show the forms of oblique stem of the numeral ‘two’ in the contexts ‘One did, and two did not’ and ‘One cow follows two (cows)’. The form qʼuˤn- is attested everywhere.

title: Lexical item for ‘very’
text: The map shows lexical items for the concept ‘very’. The context elicited: ‘Madina is a very beautiful girl’.

title: Inflection of the first person singular pronoun
text: The maps show the absolutive and the ergative forms of the first person singular pronoun ‘I’. For the absolutive the context ‘I am Rutul’ was elicited, and for the ergative — ‘I said so’.

title: Inflection of the first person singular pronoun
Inflection of the first person singular pronoun
Inclusive/exclusive distinction
text:
The map shows whether exclusive reference (‘we, but not you’) and inclusive reference (‘we, including you’) are formally distinguished. We used two contexts: ‘You did not see us’ (exclusive) and ‘We are all human beings’ (inclusive).
The distinction is PRESENT in Khnov where two different pronouns are used: inclusive jinewi and exclusive juˁqumbɨ.
The distinction is OPTIONAL in Kufa, Rutul and Kiche. For exclusive reference the form je is used, and for inclusive reference — the form je wɨ (juxtaposition of two pronouns, lit. ‘we you (sg.)’). In our data this distinction is optional, i.e. je could be used in place of je wɨ.
In the rest of the villages the distinction is ABSENT.
The case of Ikhrek needs to be discussed in more detail. According to (Ibragimov 2004: 181), Ikhrek does not have inclusive/exclusive distinction. Yet, two forms are used for 1PL — ži and ji (cf. the form for 1PL je in Kina and ži in Shinaz). Ibragimov (ibid.) states that these forms are in free distribution, and that ži is used more often. Authier (2021: 215) suggests that the two pronouns in Ikhrek distinguishes the inclusive (ji) and the exclusive (ži). Our field data does not support this claim and confirms Ibragimov’s statement. Both ji and ži were used in inclusive and exclusive contexts. Our first consultant used ji for both contexts, and the second consultant used ži for the inclusive and ji for the exclusive (which is the distribution opposite to the one observed by Authier). We collected some additional data (not presented on the map). These data supports the claim that the distribution of these forms does not correlate with inclusive/exclusive distinction. Both answers from Ikhrek are thus labeled as ABSENT.

title: Headless adjective declension: non-human reference
text: The maps show the morphological marking of a headless adjective with non-human reference in absolutive, ergative and dative cases, in singular and plural (see also feature for human reference). The contexts elicited: ‘[About cows:] The black one saw the white one’ (ABS.SG), ‘The black ones saw the white ones’ (ABS.PL), ‘The white cow sleeps, and the black one eats grass.’ (ERG.SG), ‘The white cows sleep, and the black ones eat grass.’ (ERG.PL), ‘[About cows:] The black one saw the white one’ (DAT.SG), ‘[About cows:] The black ones saw the white ones’ (DAT.PL).

title: Fusion in you.sg-ERG I-ABS construction
text: Usually in the transitive construction ‘You (singular) do X on me’, A-participant (‘you(SG)’) is in the ergative form, and P-participant (‘I’) is in the absolutive form. In some Rutul varieties the ergative marker can be dropped: wa-d zɨ jeta-s-ɨ [you(SG)-ERG I.ABS 1.kick-INF-FUT] → wa zɨ jeta-s-ɨ [you(SG)(ERG) I.ABS 1.kick-INF-FUT] ‘You will beat me!’. In different idioms the presence of the ergative marker on ‘you(SG)’ can be obligatory (OK wa-d, *wa), optional (OK wa-d, OK wa) and absent (*wa-d, OK wa) (see also feature). The map shows the status of the ergative marker (OBLIGATORY, OPTIONAL and ABSENT) on ‘you(SG)’ in the context ‘You will beat me!’.

title: Expression of the meaning ‘at least’
text: The map shows the means of expressing the meaning ‘at least’ in the context ‘At least buy (some) apples’. The distinction is made between three non-cognate words: hadana (and its variants haadan / hadan / dan), bet (and its variant pet) and man. Note that hadana and bet are verb modifiers and man is an enclitic, but in our data these words are mostly interchangeable, except for one response from Luchek where hadan and man were used together (ečbɨr hadan lewša=man ‘At least buy (some) apples’). Also relatively frequently the Russian expression χotʲa bɨ ‘at least’ (and its variants χotʲ bɨ / χotʲa / χotʲ) was used. A special construction with the verbal form jišijne (lit. ‘if become’) was attested in Khnov. Occasional periphrases meaning ‘somehow’, ‘a few’, ‘if you can’, ‘there is no choise’ were coded as OTHER.

title: Contrastive attributive marker
text: The map shows the form of the contrastive marker on attributive in constructions like ‘the X which is ATTR, in contrast to other Xs’ in the following contexts: ‘The older brother left, but the younger stayed’, ‘One is working, the other is resting’ and ‘Milk exactly the white cow’. Except for Khnov and Kiche, the form =baj / =bɨj / =bej was used. In Khnov and Kiche the marker has the form =ki. Cases when the marker was not used are listed as NO DATA.

title: Agreement slot in the adjective ‘hot’
text: There are four genders in Rutul — 1 (masculine), 2 (feminine), 3 (mostly animals + other things), 4 (some animals + other things). Usually adjectives in Rutul do not agree in gender, however, in Ikhrek variety some adjectives have an agreement slot. One of these adjectives is ‘hot’ (see also ‘good’ and ‘young’). For ‘hot’ we collected two contexts with Gender 3 and Gender 4: ‘hot milk’ and ‘hot water’, respectively. The corresponding forms of ‘hot’ are the following: wirikʼedɨ nek ‘hot milk’ (Gender 3), rikʼed xed ‘hot water’ (Gender 4). The map shows whether such agreement slot is present in the word ‘hot’. The label OTHER for used for answers which contain other lexeme for ‘hot’, not bik’erdɨ or its cognates.

title: Agreement in obliqueness: numerals
text: Most numerals agree with the noun in nominative in gender: mɨje-r wɨǧɨldɨ ‘eight men’ (Gender 1), mɨje-b zer ‘eight cows’ (Gender 3), but when the noun is in the oblique case (i. e. the case other than nominative) there is no gender agreement marking on the numeral, and the form ending in -d / -dɨ is used (e. g. mɨj-dɨ / mɨje-d edemijer (ERG) ‘eight men (ERG)’). This is called the agreement in obliqueness, and it is attested in all the villages. We used two contexts to verify the presence of it in the idiom: ‘Eight men came’ (ABS) and ‘Eight men built a house’ (ERG).

title: Adverbial -na as depictive
text: Nouns in the secondary predication can have special adverbial form with marker -na, which expresses depictive meaning — ‘X does Y [being] Z’. The map shows whether such marker is present (YES) or not (NO) on the noun ‘child’ in the elicited context ‘When I was a child, I did not sleep well’ (lit. ‘Being a child, I did not sleep well’). In case when the adverbial form was not attested, the temporal marker -ga on noun (‘when being Z’) was used.

title: Adjectival predication ‘be A’
text: The maps show the marking on the adjective in adjectival predication in the contexts ‘The apple is red’ and ‘The woman is good’. The marking include: retaining of the attributive suffix -d / -dɨ (the value ATTR), a dedicated suffix (its form is given in the value: -a, -ɨ or -e) or absence of marking altogether (the value UNMARKED). Retaining of the attributive suffix is attested everywhere, thus the value ATTR is given only when no other strategy was observed.

title: ü in native nouns
text: The front close rounded vowel /ü/ seems to appear independently in Kina and not be in a complementary distribution with other vowels. [@danielfilatovms §1.3] Some dialectal variation is reported: for Mukhad Rutul Ibragimov [@ibragimov2004] describes /ü/ as a marginal phoneme, while in Myukhrek it is described as phonetic realisation occurring before palatalized consonants, and in Khnov as having greater functional load. It is attested in 3 types of contexts: as a result of morphological operation of umlautization (see features [@Vowel fronting in APL @Paradigm levelling of šu “brother” @Fronting of u to ü in plural verbal stems]), in Azeri loanwords (see feature [@ü in loanwords]) and in a few native roots. This feature examines the inter-dialectal variation in the latter occurrences of ü. Preliminary values are the first vowels in inter-dialectal congates of Kina lexemes /nüšej/ ‘ewe aged 1-3 years’, /tʼüʔ/ ‘woolen rope’, /dükʼʲ/ ‘millet’, /tükʲ/ ‘a type of rat’, /dükar/ ‘baby’, /kučʼur/ ‘start.PFV’, /čünʲk/ ‘whip’ and /üʔü/ ‘a type of puddle’. Final values are u / uˁ (grouped together as back rounded vowels), i, e, ɨ and ü . Potential sources of ü in native lexemes listed are the influence of palatalised consonants on *u, influence of labialized consonants on *i, vowel harmony tendencies and the mutation of pharyngealized *uˁ.

title: Sound f from reconstructed labialized x
text: Generally, labialization on velar fricatives has a tendency to fall off and be infrequent across dialects. With regards to *xʷ, labialization is neutralized in several ways: it can simply disappear, for example, in word-final position; it can change the [round] feature of neighbouring vowels, if they are [+high, −low] (in this scenario /x/ still remains labialized on the surface level), or, finally, it can change the /x/ to /f/ or /ɸ/. This particular feature describes the presence ot absence of the latter change (xʷ > f). I suppose, that the conditions where it happened vary, for example, it often doesn’t happen when [xʷ] occurs next to /u/; social variation, lexical variation and free distribution between [xʷ] and [f] are also found. To avoid the outcomes being informed by inaccurate generalizations, I test multiple inter-dialectal words where *xʷ occurs in different contexts: word-finally and word-initially, before low and before high vowels, before rounded and unrounded vowels. In practice, we diagnose this by asking for cognates of a number of lexemes with the sound xʷ appearing in surface form in diaclects that reliably didn’t undergo the xʷ > f change. These are /kʼuxʲ ~ kʼuf/ ‘beak’, /maxʷ ~ maf/ ‘light spring rain, fog’, /uxun ~ ufun/ ‘stomach’, /xul ~ fɨl/ ‘mold’, /paxʷ ~ paf/ ‘pufball mushroom’, /xʷam ~ fam/ ‘den’, /čalaxʷ ~ čalaf/ ‘honeycomb, bark, woodchips’. The sounds in check (preliminary values) are the sounds in place of *xʷ plus their neigboring vowels, if the [+round] occurs on them too. In final values, values xʷ / xu / ux are grouped together as [xʷ], and values f / uf / fu are grouped together as [f]. Values kʷ / šʷ / h / x that occured occasionally are marked as OTHER (not applicable). Note that the feature is formulated in a way that doesn’t assume the phonological status of [f] and [xʷ], we only look at what allophones occur in certain historical positions.

title: Sound f from reconstructed labialized x

Sound f from reconstructed labialized x
Rounding of â before labialized stops
text: A sound like /ö/, namely a mid front or central rounded vowel, appears in the inventories across dialects contigently. A particular potential source for it is a realization of phoneme /â/ before a labialized consonant, see /â/ sometimes described as /o/ for Luchek. [@danielfilatovms §1.2] Overall, reconstruted *a in *CaCʲ, which we denote by /â/, can realize in a variety of centralized vowels, like ɜ, ɞ, o, ö, ɨ, aˁ, ä and a, as they were transcribed during the interviews. Here we measure all the possible inter-dialectal correspondences between the first vowel in cognates of Rutul /ekul/ ‘nest’. The sounds in check (preliminary values) are the last vowels. In this feature, ä / e / aˁ / ɜ are grouped together as e-like and values ö / o / ɞ are grouped as ö-like.

title: Rounding of â before labialized stops
Possible reflexes of reconstructed a
text: Reconstructed proto Rutul *a gave a lot of possible reflexes across modern dialects. According to the common assumption, difference in palatalization of the neighbouring vowels resulted in different reflexes. Roughly, *CʲaC gave fronted ä and e, and reconstruted a in *CaCʲ, which we denote by /â/, can realize in a variety of centralized vowels, like ɜ, ɞ, o, ö, ɨ, aˁ, ä and a, as they were transcribed during the interviews. (Please correct me, I’m talking about a rough tendency here). This is an ‘umbrella-feature’, documenting many inter-dialectal roots that potentially have a reflex of *a. It is meant not to check which varieties underwent a particular sound change, but to see, which groupings naturally occur on a random arbitrary set of roots. The sounds in check (preliminary values) are the first vowels in cognates of Kina words /bel/ ‘forehead’, /hejeg/ ‘pot’, /ǯad/ ‘forge’, /kʼatʼ/ ‘chicken’, xed ‘water’, /čʼar/ ‘a hair’, /ekul/ ‘nest’ and /netʼ/ ‘nit’. In this feature, the values ɜ / ɞ / o / ö are grouped together as realizations of /â/ (on this variation, see feature [@Rounding of â before labialized stops]), other values are presented as they are.

title: ö in loanwords
text: A sound like /ö/, namely a mid front or central rounded vowel, appears in the inventories across dialects contigently. A particular potential source for it are Azeri loawords with /ö/. In most instances, Azeri /ö/ is rendered as /e/. Here we measure the geographic determinant of retaining the /ö/ by asking for cognates of the inter-dialectal lexeme /güzge/ ‘mirror’ (cf. modern Az. güzgü). The sounds in check (preliminary values) are the final vowels. The values are ä / e for adaptation with /e/ and ö for retaining /ö/. Most importantly, we don’t characterize this distinction as always phonological. Among some speakers both values were interchangeable. Among others [ö] appeared in first response or fast speech but when asked to name what sound there is or in careful speech [e] occured. It is also worth mentioning that if /ü/ was adopted as /u/ in the first syllable, /ö/ was always adopted as /e/ in the second syllable.

title: lexical palatalization in coda
text: In Kina and other varieties of Rutul palatalized consonants occur not only before a front vowel. Consonants may be palatalized for reasons besides co-articulation, moreover, this can result in meaningful contrasts. [@danielfilatovms §2.7] Palatalization can derive from contraction of the following front vowel, which happens when a morpheme ending on a front vowel attaches to a morpheme beginning with a vowel. However, sometimes fronted velars (/k/, /g/, /x/, supposedly /ɣ/) and /lʲ/ occur morpheme-internally, most frequently in syllable codas and after a front vowel. This feature examines the consistency of such coda palatalization among dialects. In practice, we diagnose this by asking for cognates of one arbitrary set of Kina lexemes with and without coda palatalization after a front vowel: /begʲ/ ‘side (body part)’, /eg/ ‘horseshoe’; /uˁrdegʲ/ ‘wild duck’, /jileg/ ‘iron’; /külekʲ/ ‘elbow’, /nek/ ‘milk’; /vixʲ/ ‘shed’, /rixcʼɨr/ ‘sixty’; ‘tar, gum’ /bekʼʲ/, /jikʼʲ/ ‘heart’; /jimel/ ‘donkey’, /mel/ ‘collective work’; /šibilʲ/ ‘gravel’, /süpel/ ‘whisker, moustache(SG)’. The sounds in check (preliminary values) are the final consonants and the 1st syllable final in /rixʲcʼɨr/. Final values are palatalized for fronted velars and lʲ, and not palatalized for others. Note that the feature doesn’t aim to analyze phonology, merely the surface forms obseved.

title: Claimed geminates in intervocal position
text: In the literature several lexemes in Kina [@danielfilatovms §2.2], Myukhrek and Ikhrek [@ibragimov2004 pp. 143, 167] dialects are described as «geminates» or «strong», and for Shinaz dialects the absence of geminates is stated as a dialectal feature. Colloquially the term geminate can mean very different ideas about a consonant: for some ND languages it means unaspirated voiceless stops. Sometimes it means consonants that are lengthened, but not necessarily unaspirated (Some link). For Mukhad Ibragimov [@ibragimov2004 pp. 124, 262] states that strong consanants are such underlying segments that are realized like an aspirated stop in word-final and word-initial positions and like a voiced stop in V_V. Geminates are said to be inherited from Proto-Rutul geminates. In practice, I tested several lexemes that are reported to have geminates or long stops for inter-dialectal cognates: /rɨˁɢːɨˁd/ ‘ash(ATR)’, /jigːid/ ‘tough, rigid’, /jedːal/ ‘to ache’, /qudːum/ ‘nape of the neck, temple’, /niɢːä/ ‘(straw)berry’, /kʼedːal/ ‘clay, dirt’, /rigːizan/ ‘doorstep’, /gigːu/ ‘cuckoo’, /hɨkɨs/ ‘become’, /jakʷas/ ‘morning’, /maɢʷːal/ ‘nettle’. Turns out, from a historical perspective what is named geminates can emerge in many different ways. Some geminates inter-dialectally map to consonant clusters. Some geminates appear with a longer duration almost everywhere, disproving the predictions made by Ibragimov. The sounds in check (preliminary values) are the exact reflexes that are found in V_V position. For most observations I measured duration and voicing of the stop and annotated the value based on those. Values tː, qː, qˁː, kʷː, qʷː are grouped as typical geminates and tagged voiceless geminate, values d̥ː, ɢ̥ː, ɢ̥ˁː, ɢ̥ʷː, g̥ː, g̥ʷː are tagged voiced geminate (chances are, there might be no systematic distinction between the groups of geminates). Values tʷ, qˁ, t, tʲ, kʲ, kʷ, qʷ are grouped as voiceless (unaspirated). Values ɢ̥ˁ, ɢ̥ , d̥, g̥, d̥ʲ, ɢ̥ʷ, g̥ʷ are grouped as partially voiced. Values d, ɢ̆, dʲ, gʲ, gʷ are grouped as fully voiced. Values χ, χʷ (in uvulars for some speakers) are grouped as spirantized (correct me, I couldn’t make an assumption about which group they must belong to). Values kʰʷ, kʰ, qʰʷ, kx, tsʲ, sʲ (realizations of tʰ in some dialects), tʰʲ, kʰʲ, tʰ, tʰʷ, qχˁ, χˁ, qʰˁ are grouped as aspirated. Finally, values gʲm, kʲm, kʰʲm, gm in /rigːizan/ and md in /kʼedːal/ are grouped as consonant clusters.

title: Change of a to o before labialized stops
text: In a simple rule, some dialects are expected to have an a > o / _[+cons, +round] phonetic alternation or sound change. By this rule, /a/ is rounded before a labialized consonant. In practice, we diagnose this by asking for cognates of two Kina word forms (which find a cognate in most dialects): /ʁagʷas/ ‘to see’ and /maɢːʷal/ ‘nettle’. The sounds in check (preliminary values) are the vowels in the first syllable and the consonants after it. In final values, values aw / äCʷ / eCʷ / and cognate not given (N/A) are grouped together as not matching the sample, marked as OTHER, values agʷ / aɢʷ / aɢːʷ / aqʷ are grouped together as having the sound [a], and values ogʷ / oɢʷ as having [o]. It’s important to note that I don’t know enough to interpret the phonological nature of the combinations. I consider only labialization in the surface form: regardless of whether it is intrinsic or due to proximity to a rounded vowel. Same applies for o ~ a alternation: we can’t assume whether the distinction has been phonologised or it is a surface-level alternation.

title: Change of a to o before labialized stops
Change of a to o before labialized stops
Temporary recipient marking
text: We elicited the context ‘Give me your hand’ and ‘Give me back (my) knife’. The maps show the case marking on the pronoun ‘me’ in these contexts. The attested variants include: -da / -dda / -dɨ / -d and -s (attested only in Dzhilikhur).

title: Subject marking in age constructions
text: We elicited the context ‘I am 20 years old’. This map shows which marker is used on the human NP referring to the person whose age is predicated (in our case, first person singular pronoun). Variants include -dɨ / -d (attributive marker) or case marker -χda.

title: Predicative possessor marking
text: We elicited two contexts with predicative possessors: ‘Fatima has two children’ (affirmative) and ‘Rasul does not have a car’ (negative). The maps show the markers used on the possessor in these contexts, including -χda, -χdɨ and -d (attested with only one consultant, in Amsar).

title: Plural of the noun ‘cow’
text: The singular absolutive of the noun ‘cow’ varies as following: zer, zʲer, zär and zʲär (see feature). The plural absolutive is irregular in that it loses /r/ of the root: zebɨr (and its phonetic variants: zʲebɨr, zʲäbɨr) and zʲebir / zebir. The map shows the variation in plural forms.

title: Plural marker of the noun ‘son’
text: The singular absolutive of the noun ‘son’ is duχ. The map shows the marker that is used in plural absolutive. The attested variants include: -rä (attested in Luchek and Kiche), -ra (in Ikhrek, Myukhrek, Dzhilikhur and Khnov) and -re (elsewhere).

title: Plural marker of the noun ‘dog’
text: The singular absolutive of the noun ‘dog’ is tɨla / tala and χij (only in Khnov). The map shows the marker that is used in plural absolutive. The attested variants include: -jer (attested in Dzhilikhur, Shinaz and from some speakers in Kina, Kala, Amsar), -ʔir / -iːr (attested only Ikhrek) and -jmar (elsewhere). In case of Khnov, due to distinct lexical item (χij) the value is labeled as OTHER.

title: Plural marker of the noun ‘brother’
text: The singular absolutive of the noun ‘brother’ is either šuˤ (attested only in Khnov), šugu (attested only in Ikhrek) or šu (elsewhere). The attested variants of the plural marker include -be (and its phonetic variants) and -jmar. The latter forms either a simple — šugu-jmar (in Ikhrek), or a double marked plural — šu-be-jmar (and its phonetic variants). The map shows the distribution of the variants.

title: Phonetic variation in the noun ‘cow’
text: The map shows phonetic variation in the absolutive singular of ‘cow’. The attested forms are zer, zʲer, zär and zʲär.

title: Oblique stem of the attributive form in the ergative singular
text: The maps show how the oblique stem of attributive referring to humans is formed. We asked two contexts with three attributives: ‘The tall (person) picked apples, and the short (person) was holding a ladder’ and ‘Lame (person) did all the work’. Three variants of stem formants are attested: -nij / -ni (in Rutul, Kufa, Kiche and Kala), -na (in Shinaz and Khnov) and -naw / -now / -nɨw / -nu (elsewhere). For example, for the form alkʼa-nɨw-ɨ [lame-OBL-ERG], cf. with absolutive form alkʼa-d [lame-ATTR], the formant -nɨw is used to form an oblique stem.

title: Oblique stem of the attributive form in the ergative singular

Oblique stem ending in a sonorant
text: We collected a set of 15 nouns with oblique stems in sonorant in attributive form. The maps show the sonorant that is present in an oblique stem formant: /r/ (value: R, e. g. git-ɨr-dɨ [cat-OBL-ATTR]), /l/ (value: L, e. g. naʁ-ul-dɨ [teardrop-OBL-ATTR]), /j/ (value: J, e. g. naʁ-uji-d [teardrop-OBL-ATTR]) or NO CONSONANT, if there is none.

Marking of personal lative
text: We elicited the context with a personal lative construction: ‘Come to Rasul’s (place) in the evening’. The map shows the marking on the noun ‘Rasul’. The attested variants include: case markers -χda / -χdɨ / -χd, -k (attested only in Khnov), -χdal (attested with only one consultant, in Khnov) and noun in attributive with a postposition — -dɨ bejda (attested only in Kiche).

title: Marking of personal elative
text: We elicited two contexts with personal elative construction: ‘(Mom will be back soon), she has left Fatima’s (place)’ and ‘The guests have left Rasul’s (place)’. The map shows the marking on the nouns ‘Fatima’ and ‘Rasul’. The attested variants include: case markers -χdaː, -qla / -χla, -kla / -klʲa, -aːla and the noun in attributive with a postposition — -dɨ ǯigijaː / -d ǯigijaː, -d ǯigijaːla. In one case in Shinaz the postposition ǯigijaː is attached directly to the absolutive form. Noun phrase -d χalaː ‘from one’s house’ is also attested once (Amsar).

title: Lexical item for ‘cowshed’
text: We elicited the word for ‘cattle shed’ in the context ‘Cow is in the cattle shed’. The noun was elicited in the inessive. On the map, the stems of the lexical items are shown rather than their full forms in the context. The stems are not necessarily actual oblique stems, but rather labels that represent the lexemes. The lexemes for ‘cattle shed’ are the following: tawli- / towli- (attested in Myukhrek and Dzhilikhur) and wixʲ- (attested elsewhere).

title: Expression of the spatial meaning of proximity
text: We elicited the context ‘My house is near the river’. The map shows the marking on the noun ‘river’. The attested variants include: case markers — -da / -dɨ / -de / -d, -a (attested with only one consultant, in Khnov) and noun in attributive form with spatial postpositions — -dɨ bejda / -dɨ bejdɨ / -dɨ begede, -dɨ surudɨ (attested with only one consultant, in Luchek), -dɨ janda (attested only in Khnov).

title: Expression of the spatial meaning of proximity
Expression of the spatial meaning ‘towards inside a mass’
text: We elicited the context ‘I added (some) flour into the dough’. The map shows the case marking on the noun ‘dough’. The attested variants include: -k / -kʲ and -šdä (attested with only one consultant, in Kiche).

title: Expression of the spatial meaning ‘towards inside a mass’
Expression of the spatial meaning ‘on top of’
text: We elicited the context ‘The butterfly is on the flower’. The map shows the marking on the noun ‘flower’. The attested variants include: -iː / -ɨː / -ij / -ɨ / -i and -j (attested only in Ikhrek). We consider -ij and -j to be phenomena of different nature. We assume the latter to be a separate marker used in Ikhrek, following (Ibragimov 2004: 174). As for the former, it is a phonetic variant of marker -iː / -ɨː / -ij / -ɨ / -i, that was attested with only one consultant, in Amsar.

title: Expression of the spatial meaning ‘on top of’
Expression of the spatial meaning ‘inside the house’
text: We elicited the context ‘I am at home’. The map shows the marking on the noun ‘house’. The attested variants include: -a (zɨ χal-a a) or no marker — ZERO (zɨ χal-Ø a).

title: Expression of the spatial meaning ‘inside the house’
Expression of the spatial meaning ‘in contact with’
text: We elicited the context ‘The painting is on the wall’. The map shows the case marking on the noun ‘wall’. The attested variants include: -k / -kʲ, -χda / -χd, -χdɨgɨr (attested with only one consultant, in Khnov), -a (attested only in Khnov) and -ɨ (attested with only one consultant, in Ikhrek).

title: Expression of the spatial meaning ‘in contact with’
Expression of the spatial meaning ‘in between’
text: We elicited the context ‘Musa hid in between the stones’. The map shows the marking on the noun ‘stones’. The attested variants include: case marker -χda and attributive form of a noun with spatial postpositions — -dɨ jɨˁqʼaχda, -d jɨˁqʼa / -d jɨˁqʼ and -d arida / -d aride / -d arɨdɨ, -d arij / -dɨ arij.

title: Expression of the spatial meaning ‘in between’
Expression of the spatial meaning ‘from the top of’
text: We elicited the context ‘The frog got off the rock’. The map shows the marking on the noun ‘rock’. The attested variants include: -Vːla / -Vːlɨ / -aːl (long vowel), -Vla / -Vlɨ (short vowel) and -ja (attested only in Ikhrek).

title: Expression of the spatial meaning ‘from the top of’
Expression of the spatial meaning ‘from in contact with’
text: We elicited the context ‘Musa took the painting off the wall’. The map shows the case marking on the noun ‘wall’. The attested variants include: -kla / -kʲla / -klʲa, -ka (attested only in Ikhrek), -aːla (attested only in Khnov) and -qla / -χla.

title: Expression of the spatial meaning ‘from in contact with’
Expression of the spatial meaning ‘following, after’
text: We elicited the context ‘A dog was running after us’. The map shows the marking on the pronoun ‘us’. The attested variants include: -dɨ ǯibra / -dɨ ǯubra / -dɨ ǯɨbra (attested in every village) and -χda (attested from some speakers in Ikhrek, Khnov and Kiche).

title: Expression of the spatial meaning ‘following, after’
Ergative marker: variation in the presence of vowel
text: Ergative marker may be of r-type (balʁu-ra [fish.OBL-ERG]) or non-r-type (gagaj-e [uncle-ERG], gagaj-Ø [uncle-ERG]), see feature. Apart from that, it may either contain (balʁu-ra [fish.OBL-ERG], gagaj-e [uncle-ERG]) or lack (balʁu-r [fish.OBL-ERG], gagaj-Ø [uncle-ERG]) final vowel. For the presence of vowel in the first reaction, see feature. This feature shows whether an alternative to the first reaction is also possible in terms of vocalic vs. non-vocalic ergative marker. For example, if the speaker’s first reaction was balʁu-ra [fish.OBL-ERG], we asked if it is possible to say balʁu-r, and vice versa. If the alternative variant is possible, we report variation. We elicited four nouns in the singular and in the plural: ‘uncle’ (SG) and ‘uncle’ (PL) (animate, human), ‘fish’ (SG) and ‘fish’ (PL) (animate, non-human), ‘river’ (SG) and ‘rock’ (PL) (inanimate, non-human). The elicited contexts were as follows: ‘(My) uncle helped me to build a house’, ‘(My) uncles helped me to build a house’, ‘The fish (SG) ate the fly’, ‘The fish (PL) ate the flies’, ‘The river demolished the bridge’, ‘The rocks broke the roof’. The maps show whether variation between vocalic ergative marker vs. non-vocalic ergative marker is attested.

Ergative marker type of the singular attributive
text: Likewise to nouns (see feature), we classified the variants of the ergative marker of attributives into r-type (e.g. alkʼa-nu-ra [lame-OBL-ERG]) and non-r-type (e.g. alkʼa-nɨw-ɨ [lame-OBL-ERG], alkʼa-now-Ø [lame-OBL-ERG]). We elicited three attributives referring to humans: ‘tall’, ‘short’ and ‘lame’. The elicited contexts were as follows: ‘The tall (person) picked apples, and the short (person) was holding a ladder’ and ‘Lame (person) did all the work’. The maps show the type (r-type or non-r-type) of the ergative marker used in each of the attributives, respectively.

title: Ergative marker type of the singular attributive
Ergative marker type of the singular attributive
Ergative marker type of the singular attributive
Comitative marker
text: The maps show the variation of the comitative marker as represented in two elicited contexts: ‘Rasul went hunting with a dog’ and ‘Rasul went to Makhachkala by car’. The markers attested are the following: -kʷan, -kan, -xʷan, -xan, -fan. The variants -kʷan and -kan are attested in Kina, Luchek, Amsar and Kiche, -fan is attested in Ikhrek and Khnov, -xan is attested in Ikhrek and Rutul. The last variant, -xʷan is attested everywhere except Kina, Luchek and Khnov. The label OTHER is used if the meaning is expressed by means other than a nominal suffix but by a construction with a locative copula: χana, χan, xʷana.

title: Attributive marker
text: Attributive marker can be either -dɨ, either -d. We asked nine contexts, six with the head ‘knife’: ‘(my) brother’s knife’ (dependent noun in attributive, head in nominative), ‘I slaughtered a sheep with (my) brother’s knife’ (dependent noun in attributive, head in oblique case), ‘sharp knife’ (dependent adjective, head in nominative), ‘He slaughtered a sheep with a sharp knife’ (dependent adjective, head in oblique case), ‘my knife’ (dependent personal pronoun in attributive, head in nominative), ‘He slaughtered a sheep with my knife’ (dependent personal pronoun in attributive, head in oblique case). And three contexts with the head ‘dog’: ‘lame dog’ (dependent adjective), ‘my dog’ (dependent personal pronoun in attributive), ‘(my) brother’s dog’ (dependent noun in attributive). The difference between the words ‘knife’ and ‘dog’ is that ‘knife’ is a noun of 4th gender class, and ‘dog’ — of 3rd gender class. These maps show the variation of attributive markers in these nine contexts.

title: Agreement in obliqueness
text: The map shows whether the form of the attributive (possessor) noun depends on the case of the head noun (agreement in obliqueness). We elicited three contexts: ‘(my) brother’s knife’ (the head noun ‘knife’ is in the nominative and belongs to Gender 4), ‘I slaughtered a sheep with (my) brother’s knife’ (the head noun ‘knife’ is in an oblique case and belongs to Gender 4), ‘(my) brother’s dog’ (the head noun ‘dog’ is in the nominative and belongs to Gender 3). In Ikhrek and Khnov, the first contexts shows the attributive suffix -d (šuˤ-d kantʼ [brother-ATTR knife]), and -dɨ in the two other contexts -dɨ (šuˤ-dɨ kantʼi-fan [brother-ATTR knife.OBL-COMIT]; šuˤ-dɨ χij [brother-ATTR dog]). In other dialects the suffix -dɨ is used in all contexts. In (Tairova 2010) it is claimed that the same two variants of the attributive suffix are distributed depending on the gender and number of the head in Myukhrek; no details are given as to the case of the head. We cannot directly confirm this based on our data, because, for Myukhrek, the three contexts come from different consultants, so Myukhrek is not shown on the map. However, if we merge the data coming from all consultants, Myukhrek does group not with Khnov and Ikhrek but with the other dialects; and does not confirm Tairova’s [-@tairova2010] account.

title: Associative plural marking
text: A construction consisting of a noun X denoting human with an associative plural marker means ‘X and his associates (family, etc.)’. We elicited the context ‘Rasul’s (family) came’. The map shows the associative plural marking on the noun ‘Rasul’. The attested variants include: -ar, -quˁner / -quner, -qun / -quna, -qušdɨbɨr, -ašdɨbɨr / -ašidbɨ, -ašdɨ, -dɨbɨr / -ɨdbɨ, -ɨbɨr, -(aš)dɨ bejdebɨr.

title: Capability subject marking
text: We elicited two contexts with capability subjects: ‘My brother can swim across the river’ (affirmative) and ‘Rasul couldn’t lift this stone’ (negative). The maps show the markers used on the capability subjects in these contexts, including -daː, -dːa and -da (attested with only one consultant, in Amsar).

title: Ergative marker type
text: We classified the variants of the ergative marker into r-type (e.g. balʁu-ra [fish.OBL-ERG]) and non-r-type (e.g. gagaj-e [uncle-ERG], gagaj-Ø [uncle-ERG]). We elicited four nouns in the singular and in the plural: ‘uncle’ (SG) and ‘uncle’ (PL) (animate, human), ‘fish’ (SG) and ‘fish’ (PL) (animate, non-human), ‘river’ (SG) and ‘rock’ (PL) (inanimate, non-human). The elicited contexts were as follows: ‘(My) uncle helped me to build a house’, ‘(My) uncles helped me to build a house’, ‘The fish (SG) ate the fly’, ‘The fish (PL) ate the flies’, ‘The river demolished the bridge’, ‘The rocks broke the roof’. The maps show the type (r-type or non-r-type) of the ergative marker used in each of the contexts, respectively.

title: Ergative marker: presence of vowel
text: Ergative marker may be of r-type (balʁu-ra [fish.OBL-ERG]) or non-r-type (gagaj-e [uncle-ERG], gagaj-Ø [uncle-ERG]), see feature. Apart from that, it may either contain (balʁu-ra [fish.OBL-ERG], gagaj-e [uncle-ERG]) or lack (balʁu-r [fish.OBL-ERG], gagaj-Ø [uncle-ERG]) final vowel. This feature considers the first reaction to the stimuli, for the second reaction, i.e. the possibility of an alternative form, see feature. We elicited four nouns in the singular and in the plural: ‘uncle’ (SG) and ‘uncle’ (PL) (animate, human), ‘fish’ (SG) and ‘fish’ (PL) (animate, non-human), ‘river’ (SG) and ‘rock’ (PL) (inanimate, non-human). The elicited contexts were as follows: ‘(My) uncle helped me to build a house’, ‘(My) uncles helped me to build a house’, ‘The fish (SG) ate the fly’, ‘The fish (PL) ate the flies’, ‘The river demolished the bridge’, ‘The rocks broke the roof’. The maps show the presence of the vowel in the ergative marker.

title: Expression of the spatial meaning ‘behind’
text: We elicited the context ‘The children hid behind the house’. The map shows the marking on the noun ‘house’. The attested variants include: case marker -χda and attributive form of a noun with spatial postpositions — -dɨ jɨˁqʼaχda / -dɨ jɨˁqʼaχdɨ, -dɨ quʔuna / -dɨ quna, -dɨ xala, -dɨ jɨˁqʼada, -dɨ giraʁdɨ.

title: Expression of the spatial meaning ‘from behind’
text: We elicited the context ‘The sun came out from behind the mountain’. The map shows the case marking on the noun ‘mountain’. The attested variants include: -qla / -qlaː / -qlaːl / -χla / -χlaː, -aːla / -aːl, -χdaː (attested only in Ikhrek), -kʲla / -klʲa / -klʲaː, -dɨgɨr (attested only in Khnov) and -aːda / -dːa / -daː / -da.

title: Expression of the spatial meaning ‘from behind’
Expression of the spatial meaning ‘from inside a mass’
text: We elicited the context ‘Musa catched all the fish out of the water’. The map shows the case marking on the noun ‘water’. The attested variants include: -kla / -kʲla, -ka (attested only in Ikhrek), -ɨgɨ / -ɨgɨr (attested only in Khnov), -a and -ɨːla.

title: Expression of the spatial meaning ‘from inside a mass’
Expression of the spatial meaning ‘from under’
text: We elicited the context ‘The snake came from under the stone’. The map shows the marking on the noun ‘stone’. The attested variants include: case markers -qla / -qlaː / -qlal / -χla, -xʲdaː, -χdaː, -χdɨgɨr, -kla / -kʲla / -xʲlʲa and attributive form of a noun with spatial postpositions — -d q’anʲäχla / -d q’aneχla, -d q’anixʲdaː, -dɨ q’aneχdɨgɨr, -d q’anaklaː / -dɨ q’ʷanakʲlʲaː.

title: Expression of the spatial meaning ‘from under’
Expression of the spatial meaning ‘in contact on top of’
text: We elicited the context ‘There is a stain on the table’. The map shows the case marking on the noun ‘table’. The attested variants include: -k / -kʲ, -a, -j (in Ikhrek) and -xde (attested with only one consultant, in Kiche).

title: Expression of the spatial meaning ‘in contact on top of’
Expression of the spatial meaning ‘inside a mass’
text: We elicited the context ‘There are a lot of fish in the water’. The map shows the case marking on the noun ‘water’. The attested variants include: -a / -e / ZERO (xij-e in Kina, xid-a / šid-a in Khnov and xi in Kala), -xde / -šde (xidi-xde / xidi-šde in Kiche and xidɨ-xde / xidɨ-šde in Kufa), -kʲ / -k (elsewhere, various forms: xidɨ-k, xi-k, xiji-kʲ, etc.) and -xʲ (attested with only one consultant, in Kufa). The full forms of the noun are given in brackets. While the oblique stems may vary across villages, these differences are not considered in this particular feature. For variation in oblique stem formation, see feature.

title: Expression of the spatial meaning ‘inside a mass’
Expression of the spatial meaning ‘near, by’
text: We elicited the context ‘The tree grows near the house’. The map shows the marking on the noun ‘house’. The attested variants include: case markers -da and attributive form of a noun with spatial postpositions — -dɨ bejda / -dɨ bejde / -dɨ begida / -dɨ begede, -dɨ suruda, -dɨ ulikʲ, -dɨ ulikʲlʲa, -dɨ uliχda, -dɨ janda, -dɨ xura.

title: Expression of the spatial meaning ‘near, by’
Expression of the spatial meaning ‘out of’
text: We elicited the context ‘I went out of the house’. The map shows the marking on the noun ‘house’. The attested variants include: -aː, -a (attested with only one consultant, in Dzhilikhur), -gɨr (attested only in Khnov) and -aːla (attested with only one consultant, in Shinaz).

title: Expression of the spatial meaning ‘out of’
Expression of the spatial meaning ‘under’
text: We elicited the context ‘The cat is lying under the table’. The map shows the marking on the noun ‘table’. The attested variants include: case markers -χda / -χd, -šdä / -xde, -kʲ and attributive form of a noun with spatial postpositions — -d qʼanäχdɨ / -d qʼaneχda / -d qʼaneχd, -d qʼanäkʲ / -d qʼanekʲ, -d qʼanʲašdä / -d qʼanaxde, -d saʔna, and the form -χd qʼaneχdɨ.

title: Inanimate plural marking
text: We elicited three contexts: ‘They cut down the trees’, ‘They built houses for themselves’, ‘They brought axes’. The maps show the plural marking on the nouns ‘tree’, ‘house’ and ‘axe’. The attested variants include: -bɨ (attested only in Khnov) and -bɨr (elsewhere).

title: Marking of addressee
text: We elicited the context ‘I didn’t tell him anything’. The map shows the marking on the pronoun ‘him’ (the addressee). The attested variants include: -χda (attested only in Kiche) and -da / -de / -dɨ / -dda / -d (elsewhere).

title: Marking of personal essive
text: We elicited the context with a personal essive (chezative, being at X’s place) construction: ‘Rasul lives at Magomed’s (place)’. The map shows the marking on the noun ‘Magomed’. The attested variants include: case markers — -xʷan, -χda, -k, noun phrases — -dɨ χal(a) ‘at X’s house’ and -dɨ ǯigi(j) ‘at X’s place’. In Shinaz for some speakers it is possible to employ ǯigi(j) without dependent attributive marker -dɨ.

title: Marking of standard of comparison
text: The maps show the marking of the standard of comparison in comparative constructions. We elicited two contexts: ‘The mother is kinder than the father’ and ‘A pear is sweeter than an apple’. Attested markers are as follows: -ɨːla / -iːla (and other phonetic variants), -qa / -qaʔ, -qana (attested with only one consultant, in Kiche), -χda (attested with only one consultant, in Dzhilikhur).

title: Oblique stem ending in a sonorant: presence of palatalization
text: We collected a set of 15 nouns with oblique stems in sonorant in attributive form. We distinguish between soft and hard stems. Soft stems are morphophonologically palatalized, they select oblique stem formants with front vowels /e/, /i/ (value: SOFT, e. g. ǯʷel-ir-dɨ [sheaf-OBL-ATTR]). Hard stems are morphophonologically non-palatalized, they select oblique stem formants with non-front vowels /ɨ/, /a/ (value: HARD, e. g. git-ɨr-dɨ [cat-OBL-ATTR]). The maps show the variation in stem type.
